Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Black, Brown or Asian? : Afro- and Indo-Caribbean Immigrants Encounter Race in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scholars have traditionally understood the American racial hierarchy through the lens of the "Black-White" color line, reflecting the primacy of our most historically consequential axis of racial distinction. However, the old Black-White model is increasingly inadequate for understanding racial and ethnic categories in the United States. The declining primacy of the Black-White model of race relations highlights the urgent need for scholarship on relationships between racial/ethnic minority groups. This project addresses this emerging need by examining inter-minority stratification between those classified as Black and those classified as Asian by taking advantage of the unique case of Afro and Indo-Caribbean immigrants to the United States. Both groups share similar cultural backgrounds while being classified in the United States into different racial/ethnic groups. The analysis combines a quantitative study of the earnings and residential locations of Afro and Asian Caribbean immigrants to the United States with in-depth interviews of immigrants that seek to better understand their own racial and ethnic identification in their adopted home country. This project will enrich our understanding of how inter-minority relations will likely to reshape 21st Century America's increasingly diverse, and rapidly shifting racial and ethnic landscape.

Using the case of Afro- and Indo-Caribbean immigrants, this study thus examines: (1) How Black and Asian phenotypes are being treated in the labor and housing market, controlling for cultural characteristics and human capital (2) How culturally integrated Black and Asian immigrants from the same sending societies react to American racial categories, and (3) What factors predict the kinds of ethno-racial choices that Afro- and Indo-Caribbeans make in response to US racial categories. The first question assesses the effect of racial ascription on socio-economic opportunity. The latter questions examine how racial identification may recursively reshape the prevailing racial hierarchy. A mixed-methods approach is used to answer these questions. Multivariate analyses of data from the American Community Survey's Public Use Micro-Data Samples are used to compare structural incorporation outcomes among Afro- and Indo-Caribbeans in the US. One year of ethnographic observation, and data from 120 extended interviews are used to shed light on how Afro- and Indo-Caribbean immigrants make ethno-racial choices in response to the American racial context. Fieldwork will be conducted in New York, which has long been the primary destination for Afro- and Indo-Caribbean immigrants to the US, and which today still boasts America's largest Caribbean populations. This study will shed valuable light on the evolving nature of racial/ethnic relations in 21st Century America's increasingly diverse mosaic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined incorporation experiences of Afro- and Indo-Caribbean immigrants to the US. The project builds on a research tradition that has examined the experiences of West Indian immigrants as a way of shedding light on the continuing challenges of being racialized as “Black” in American society. Prior work focused on Black West Indians and compared their experiences with those of African Americans. The current study extends this research to an examination of the experiences of “Indo-Caribbeans”, West Indians of South Asian descent, who make up roughly 40% of the population of the English Speaking Caribbean, and who constitute a substantial proportion of the U.S.-based West Indian population. The goal of the current study was to compare Afro- and Indo-Caribbean  immigrants’ experiences with race in the U.S. to shed light on evolving processes of racial stratification in our increasingly diverse American society. Unlike Afro-Caribbeans, who are racially ascribed as “Black”, Indo-Caribbeans have the opportunity to exercise “ethnic options” (Waters 1990) in the U.S. racial context – specifically, to describe themselves as “Asian” (thereby aligning themselves with U.S.-based South Asian descended communities), or to describe themselves as “Black” (aligning themselves with their West Indian co-ethnics).

The study investigated these questions through ethnography, in-depth interviews, and a custom-built survey. The ethnographic work was conducted primarily in New York City and its metro area, extending through Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, New Jersey and Long Island. Data was collected over a 12-month period. The researcher spent time in a variety of settings, including civic community organizations, churches, mosques and mandirs, local shops, restaurants and street corners. Interviews were completed with approximately 100 subjects, and survey data gathered from approximately 300 subjects. The duration of the interview was minimally 2 hours. However, a substantial proportion stretched over 4 hours, and many were conducted over multiple meetings. Social network data was also gathered during the interviews. Interviews were conducted in person. In a small number of cases, follow up conversations were also conducted over the telephone. Respondents were sampled for range in age, education level, religious affiliation, neighborhood of residence, and national origin.

The data gathered for this study is currently being analyzed. As such, conclusions from this research are pending. Results of the research will be presented in public and scholarly fora in the coming year.
